headline: Woman died after hysterectomy at private hospital

annotations.paragraph: Neglect at a private hospital contributed to the "avoidable" death of a 48-year-old woman, an inquest has found.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a key finding from an inquest related to the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: Maxine Spittlehouse underwent a hysterectomy at Kinvara Private Hospital in Rotherham, and despite "obvious" internal bleeding in the hours afterwards, was not transferred to NHS care in time to save her.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives specific details about the circumstances leading to the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: Her husband, David Spittlehouse, said: "All the symptoms were there to be seen and acted on. She was failed by those responsible for her care."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from the husband, providing personal insight into the situation.

annotations.paragraph: He said private hospitals like Kinvara, which has not responded to the BBC's requests for a statement, should not be permitted to carry out total abdominal hysterectomies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a critical opinion about the hospital's practices, relevant to the story.

annotations.paragraph: "She would want us to get justice, I know she would. If it were other way round and that had happened to me, she would have gone hell for leather," he said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal perspective on the family's pursuit of justice.

annotations.paragraph: Mrs Spittlehouse was an NHS patient, and chose Kinvara for the hysterectomy on 16 July 2024. The procedure had been advised to treat her heavy and painful periods.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about the patient's medical background and reason for the procedure.

annotations.paragraph: The doctors who performed the surgery on her checked and found no bleeding as a result of the operation, which was described in notes as "straightforward", but the seals must have failed after their checks, Doncaster Coroner's Court heard.
annotations.reason: Offers direct commentary on the surgery's outcome and subsequent complications.

annotations.paragraph: family handout
annotations.reason: This is a placeholder for an image caption and does not contribute to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Almost immediately after the procedure, at about 13:00 BST, Mrs Spittlehouse had severe abdominal pain.
annotations.reason: Describes the immediate post-operative complications experienced by the patient.

annotations.paragraph: By 01:00 BST she was "screaming in pain", vomiting, pale and unable to lie down.
annotations.reason: Details the worsening condition of the patient, contributing to the narrative of her decline.

annotations.paragraph: The "obvious" risk of internal bleeding was not established by the doctor treating her and was deemed a "gross failure" by assistant coroner Georgina Gibbs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on the medical oversight that contributed to the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: Nurses raised concerns at least three times and, at about 01:45, first suggested to the junior doctor she should be transferred to emergency care.
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds narrative progression by detailing the timeline and actions taken by the nurses.

annotations.paragraph: "Although he said, 'leave it with me', nothing did happen in that particular regard until over five hours later," the coroner said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from the coroner, highlighting the delay in response.

annotations.paragraph: By 03:20, Mrs Spittlehouse was in "a very precarious position", the coroner said, and despite one nurse "constantly" informing the doctor of this, it would be another four hours before an ambulance was called.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers critical information about the worsening condition and delayed medical response.

annotations.paragraph: The inquest heard Dr Mandela Thyoka had considered whether Mrs Spittlehouse's reaction was "related to her pain threshold".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the doctor's considerations, relevant to the case.

annotations.paragraph: Dr Dutta told the coroner he did not think it was an emergency, and he had not been told of the nurses' concerns.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary from Dr. Dutta regarding the situation.

annotations.paragraph: Ms Gibbs said: "It was not for the highly experienced consultant to be reassured by the junior doctor in circumstances where it was clear he did not understand what the cause was."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a quote that critiques the consultant's actions, relevant to the incident.

annotations.paragraph: Dr Dutta told the inquest he had given an instruction to transfer her to Rotherham Hospital immediately, but the coroner said he "may have misremembered".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides conflicting accounts about the decision to transfer the patient, relevant to the case.

annotations.paragraph: "If it was a risk, and with time being ever critical, he should have transferred her straight away," she said.
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes the urgency of the situation, relevant to the incident.

annotations.paragraph: "How much worse did it need to be? What else needed to happen before she would be transferred? He knew Kinvara was not equipped to deal with such a situation."
annotations.reason: This paragraph questions the decision-making process, directly related to the incident.

annotations.paragraph: He left the hospital at 06:50, and told the inquest he did "all he could do".
annotations.reason: This provides a timeline and direct quote relevant to the events leading to the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: At about 07:15, Dr Thyoka made a decision to call an ambulance, but without conveying the urgency of the situation, was told it could be a two-hour wait.
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds critical information about the response to the medical emergency.

annotations.paragraph: Fifteen minutes later, Mrs Spittlehouse was "tragically at the point of no return", the coroner said, and by 07:40 she had "completely shut down".
annotations.reason: This provides a timeline and coroner's statement about the severity of the situation.

annotations.paragraph: She suffered a cardiac arrest and while in theatre at Rotherham Hospital, large blood clots and uterine bleeding were found.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives essential medical details about the cause of death.

annotations.paragraph: The Spittlehouses' only child, Millie, 24, said she had put trust in the people caring for her mother.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary from the deceased's daughter, which is relevant to the story.

annotations.paragraph: "You think because it's a hospital, it's safe and it's fine, but sometimes that's not the case."
annotations.reason: This quote reflects a general sentiment about hospital safety, which is relevant to the incident.

annotations.paragraph: She said she "gets her strength" from Mrs Spittlehouse.
annotations.reason: This is a personal reflection that does not add new information about the incident.

annotations.paragraph: "She was a strong lady. Whenever I feel upset, I can always feel her."
annotations.reason: This is a personal sentiment that does not contribute new facts or context to the story.

annotations.paragraph: Speaking after the inquest, she said: "Mum lived life to the fullest."
annotations.reason: This is a personal reflection that does not provide new information about the incident.

annotations.paragraph: "She could make friends with anyone and lit up every room with her kindness, positivity and humour.
annotations.reason: This is a personal tribute and does not contribute new facts or context to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: "We loved her so very much and our lives will not be the same without her."
annotations.reason: This is a personal tribute and does not contribute new facts or context to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Mrs Spittlehouse passed away on 22 July due to a hypoxic brain injury caused by post-operative bleeding.
annotations.reason: This provides essential information about the cause and date of death, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The coroner said: "Some failures were admitted by Dr Thyoka, none were admitted by anyone else.
annotations.reason: This quote provides direct commentary on the investigation into the incident.

annotations.paragraph: "In this case there were a number of shortcomings and negligence.
annotations.reason: This statement highlights the issues and negligence involved, directly related to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: "There were no real means of dealing with the emergency at Kinvara and she should have been transferred.
annotations.reason: This quote provides direct commentary on the hospital's lack of emergency preparedness, which is relevant to the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: "Her death was an avoidable death. I do find that the high threshold of neglect is made out in this case."
annotations.reason: This quote directly addresses the issue of neglect, which is central to the story of the woman's death.

annotations.paragraph: Kinvara Private Hospital has been contacted for comment.
